trans-unit.source: Scheduling and Execution with Data Factory
trans-unit.target: Scheduling and Execution with Data Factory

trans-unit.source: Learn scheduling and execution aspects of Azure Data Factory application model.
trans-unit.target: Learn scheduling and execution aspects of Azure Data Factory application model.

trans-unit.source: This article explains the scheduling and execution aspects of Azure Data Factory application model.
trans-unit.target: This article explains the scheduling and execution aspects of Azure Data Factory application model.

trans-unit.source: This article builds on <linkText>Creating Pipelines</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Creating Datasets</linkText><title></title> articles and assumes that you understand basics of data factory application model concepts: activity, pipelines, linked services and datasets.
trans-unit.target: This article builds on <linkText>Creating Pipelines</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Creating Datasets</linkText><title></title> articles and assumes that you understand basics of data factory application model concepts: activity, pipelines, linked services and datasets.

trans-unit.source: With the scheduler section in the activity JSON, you can specify a recurring schedule for the activity.
trans-unit.target: With the scheduler section in the activity JSON, you can specify a recurring schedule for the activity.

trans-unit.source: For example you can schedule activity runs every hour as follows:
trans-unit.target: For example you can schedule activity runs every hour as follows:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Scheduler example</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Scheduler example</linkText>

trans-unit.source: As shown above, specifying an hourly schedule creates activity runs corresponding to a series of tumbling windows.
trans-unit.target: As shown above, specifying an hourly schedule creates activity runs corresponding to a series of tumbling windows.

trans-unit.source: Tumbling windows are series of fixed-sized, non-overlapping and contiguous time intervals.
trans-unit.target: Tumbling windows are series of fixed-sized, non-overlapping and contiguous time intervals.

trans-unit.source: For the currently executing activity run, the window time interval can be accessed with WindowStart and WindowEnd system variables in the activity JSON.
trans-unit.target: For the currently executing activity run, the window time interval can be accessed with WindowStart and WindowEnd system variables in the activity JSON.

trans-unit.source: You can use these variables for different purposes in your activity JSON and scripts associated with the activity including selecting data from input, output datasets representing time series data.
trans-unit.target: You can use these variables for different purposes in your activity JSON and scripts associated with the activity including selecting data from input, output datasets representing time series data.

trans-unit.source: For more information on different properties available for scheduler including scheduling at a specific time offset, setting the mode to align processing at the beginning of interval for the window or at the end please refer to the <linkText>Creating Pipelines</linkText><title></title> article.
trans-unit.target: For more information on different properties available for scheduler including scheduling at a specific time offset, setting the mode to align processing at the beginning of interval for the window or at the end please refer to the <linkText>Creating Pipelines</linkText><title></title> article.

trans-unit.source: Time series data is a continuous sequence of data points typically consisting of successive measurements made over a time interval.
trans-unit.target: Time series data is a continuous sequence of data points typically consisting of successive measurements made over a time interval.

trans-unit.source: Common examples of time series data include sensor data, application telemetry data etc.
trans-unit.target: Common examples of time series data include sensor data, application telemetry data etc.

trans-unit.source: With Azure Data Factory, you can process time series data in batched fashion with activity runs.
trans-unit.target: With Azure Data Factory, you can process time series data in batched fashion with activity runs.

trans-unit.source: Typically, there are recurring cadences at which input data arrives and output data needs to be produced.
trans-unit.target: Typically, there are recurring cadences at which input data arrives and output data needs to be produced.

trans-unit.source: This cadence is modeled by specifying availability section on the dataset as follows:
trans-unit.target: This cadence is modeled by specifying availability section on the dataset as follows:

trans-unit.source: Each unit of data consumed and produced by an activity run is called a data slice.
trans-unit.target: Each unit of data consumed and produced by an activity run is called a data slice.

trans-unit.source: The diagram below shows an example of an activity with an input time series dataset and an output time series dataset each with availability set to hourly frequency.
trans-unit.target: The diagram below shows an example of an activity with an input time series dataset and an output time series dataset each with availability set to hourly frequency.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Availability scheduler</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Availability scheduler</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The hourly data slices for the input and output dataset are shown in the diagram above.
trans-unit.target: The hourly data slices for the input and output dataset are shown in the diagram above.

trans-unit.source: The diagram shows 3 input slices that are ready for processing and the 10-11AM activity run in progress producing the 10-11AM output slice.
trans-unit.target: The diagram shows 3 input slices that are ready for processing and the 10-11AM activity run in progress producing the 10-11AM output slice.

trans-unit.source: The time interval associated with the current slice being produced can be accessed in the dataset JSON with variables SliceStart and SliceEnd.
trans-unit.target: The time interval associated with the current slice being produced can be accessed in the dataset JSON with variables SliceStart and SliceEnd.

trans-unit.source: For more information on different properties available for availability section please refer to the <linkText>Creating Datasets</linkText><title></title> article.
trans-unit.target: For more information on different properties available for availability section please refer to the <linkText>Creating Datasets</linkText><title></title> article.

trans-unit.source: Let’s put some thing together and in action by revisiting the sample for copy activity shown in the <linkText>Creating Pipelines</linkText><title></title> article that copies data from an Azure SQL table to Azure blob every hour.
trans-unit.target: Let’s put some thing together and in action by revisiting the sample for copy activity shown in the <linkText>Creating Pipelines</linkText><title></title> article that copies data from an Azure SQL table to Azure blob every hour.

trans-unit.source: Input: Azure SQL dataset
trans-unit.target: Input: Azure SQL dataset

trans-unit.source: Note that the frequency is set to Hour and interval is set to 1 in the availability section.
trans-unit.target: Note that the frequency is set to Hour and interval is set to 1 in the availability section.

trans-unit.source: Output: Azure Blob dataset
trans-unit.target: Output: Azure Blob dataset

trans-unit.source: Note that the frequency is set to Hour and interval is set to 1 in the availability section.
trans-unit.target: Note that the frequency is set to Hour and interval is set to 1 in the availability section.

trans-unit.source: Activity: Copy activity
trans-unit.target: Activity: Copy activity

trans-unit.source: The sample above shows activity schedule and dataset availability sections set to hourly frequency.
trans-unit.target: The sample above shows activity schedule and dataset availability sections set to hourly frequency.

trans-unit.source: The sample shows how you can leverage the WindowStart and WindowEnd variables to select the relevant data for the given activity run and send it to a blob with appropriate dynamic folderPath parameterized to have the folder for every hour.
trans-unit.target: The sample shows how you can leverage the WindowStart and WindowEnd variables to select the relevant data for the given activity run and send it to a blob with appropriate dynamic folderPath parameterized to have the folder for every hour.

trans-unit.source: When 3 of the slices between 8 – 11 AM execute, this is what it will look like for a sample Azure table and Blob.
trans-unit.target: When 3 of the slices between 8 – 11 AM execute, this is what it will look like for a sample Azure table and Blob.

trans-unit.source: Suppose the data in Azure SQL is as follows:
trans-unit.target: Suppose the data in Azure SQL is as follows:

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Sample input</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On deploying the above pipeline the Azure blob will populated as follows:
trans-unit.target: On deploying the above pipeline the Azure blob will populated as follows:

trans-unit.source: File mypath/2015/1/1/8/Data.<Guid>.txt with data
trans-unit.target: File mypath/2015/1/1/8/Data.<Guid>.txt with data

trans-unit.source: Note: will be replaced with an actual guid. Example file name: Data.bcde1348-7620-4f93-bb89-0eed3455890b.txt
trans-unit.target: Note: will be replaced with an actual guid. Example file name: Data.bcde1348-7620-4f93-bb89-0eed3455890b.txt

trans-unit.source: File mypath/2015/1/1/9/Data.<Guid>.txt with data:
trans-unit.target: File mypath/2015/1/1/9/Data.<Guid>.txt with data:

trans-unit.source: File mypath/2015/1/1/10/Data.<Guid>.txt with no data.
trans-unit.target: File mypath/2015/1/1/10/Data.<Guid>.txt with no data.

trans-unit.source: The Creating Pipelines article introduced the concept of active period for a pipeline specified by setting the start and end properties of the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: The Creating Pipelines article introduced the concept of active period for a pipeline specified by setting the start and end properties of the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: You can set the start date for the pipeline active period in the past and data factory will automatically calculate (back fill) all data slices in the past and will begin processing them.
trans-unit.target: You can set the start date for the pipeline active period in the past and data factory will automatically calculate (back fill) all data slices in the past and will begin processing them.

trans-unit.source: With back filled data slices, it is possible to configure them to be run in parallel.
trans-unit.target: With back filled data slices, it is possible to configure them to be run in parallel.

trans-unit.source: You can do that by setting the concurrency property in policy section of the activity JSON as shown in the Creating Pipelines article.
trans-unit.target: You can do that by setting the concurrency property in policy section of the activity JSON as shown in the Creating Pipelines article.

trans-unit.source: You can monitor execution of slices in a rich visual way.
trans-unit.target: You can monitor execution of slices in a rich visual way.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Monitoring and managing pipelines</linkText><title></title> article for details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Monitoring and managing pipelines</linkText><title></title> article for details.

trans-unit.source: Consider the following example which shows two activities.
trans-unit.target: Consider the following example which shows two activities.

trans-unit.source: Activity1 produces a time series dataset with slices as output that is consumed as input by Activity2 to produce the final output time series dataset.
trans-unit.target: Activity1 produces a time series dataset with slices as output that is consumed as input by Activity2 to produce the final output time series dataset.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Failed slice</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Failed slice</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The above diagram shows that out of 3 recent slices there was a failure producing the 9-10 AM slice for Dataset2.
trans-unit.target: The above diagram shows that out of 3 recent slices there was a failure producing the 9-10 AM slice for Dataset2.

trans-unit.source: Data factory automatically tracks dependency for time series dataset and as a result holds off kicking off the activity run for 9-10 AM downstream slice.
trans-unit.target: Data factory automatically tracks dependency for time series dataset and as a result holds off kicking off the activity run for 9-10 AM downstream slice.

trans-unit.source: Data factory monitoring & management tools allow you to drill into the diagnostic logs for the failed slice easily find the root cause for the issue and fix it. Once you have fixed the issue you can also easily kick off the activity run to produce the failed slice. For more details on how to kick off reruns, understand state transitions for data slices please refer to the <linkText>monitoring & management</linkText><title></title> article.
trans-unit.target: Data factory monitoring & management tools allow you to drill into the diagnostic logs for the failed slice easily find the root cause for the issue and fix it. Once you have fixed the issue you can also easily kick off the activity run to produce the failed slice. For more details on how to kick off reruns, understand state transitions for data slices please refer to the <linkText>monitoring & management</linkText><title></title> article.

trans-unit.source: Once you kick off the rerun and the 9-10AM slice for dataset2 is ready, data factory kicks off the run for the 9-10 AM dependent slice on final dataset as shown in the diagram below.
trans-unit.target: Once you kick off the rerun and the 9-10AM slice for dataset2 is ready, data factory kicks off the run for the 9-10 AM dependent slice on final dataset as shown in the diagram below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Rerun failed slice</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Rerun failed slice</linkText>

trans-unit.source: For deeper dive on specifying dependency and tracking the dependencies for complex chain of activities and datasets, refer to sections below.
trans-unit.target: For deeper dive on specifying dependency and tracking the dependencies for complex chain of activities and datasets, refer to sections below.

trans-unit.source: In the samples shown above, the frequencies for input and output datasets and activity schedule window were same.
trans-unit.target: In the samples shown above, the frequencies for input and output datasets and activity schedule window were same.

trans-unit.source: Some scenarios require the ability to produce output at a frequency different than frequencies of one or more inputs.
trans-unit.target: Some scenarios require the ability to produce output at a frequency different than frequencies of one or more inputs.

trans-unit.source: Data factory supports modeling these scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Data factory supports modeling these scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Consider a scenario where we have input measurement data from sensors available every hour in Azure Blob and we want to produce a daily aggregate report with statistics like mean, max, min etc... for the day with data factory <linkText>Hive activity</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Consider a scenario where we have input measurement data from sensors available every hour in Azure Blob and we want to produce a daily aggregate report with statistics like mean, max, min etc... for the day with data factory <linkText>Hive activity</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Here is how you can model this with data factory:
trans-unit.target: Here is how you can model this with data factory:

trans-unit.source: Input Azure blob dataset:
trans-unit.target: Input Azure blob dataset:

trans-unit.source: The hourly input files are dropped in the folder for the given day.
trans-unit.target: The hourly input files are dropped in the folder for the given day.

trans-unit.source: Availability for input is set Hourly (frequency: Hour, interval: 1).
trans-unit.target: Availability for input is set Hourly (frequency: Hour, interval: 1).

trans-unit.source: Output Azure blob dataset
trans-unit.target: Output Azure blob dataset

trans-unit.source: One output file will be dropped every day in the folder for the day.
trans-unit.target: One output file will be dropped every day in the folder for the day.

trans-unit.source: Availability of output is set Daily (frequency: Day and interval: 1).
trans-unit.target: Availability of output is set Daily (frequency: Day and interval: 1).

trans-unit.source: Activity: Hive activity in a pipeline
trans-unit.target: Activity: Hive activity in a pipeline

trans-unit.source: The hive script receives the appropriate datetime information as parameters leveraging the WindowStart variable as shown below.
trans-unit.target: The hive script receives the appropriate datetime information as parameters leveraging the WindowStart variable as shown below.

trans-unit.source: The hive script uses this variable to load the data from the right folder for the day and run the aggregation to generate the output.
trans-unit.target: The hive script uses this variable to load the data from the right folder for the day and run the aggregation to generate the output.

trans-unit.source: Here is how this looks like from data dependency point of view.
trans-unit.target: Here is how this looks like from data dependency point of view.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data dapendency</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data dapendency</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The output slice for every day depends on 24 hourly slices from input dataset.
trans-unit.target: The output slice for every day depends on 24 hourly slices from input dataset.

trans-unit.source: Data factory computes these dependencies automatically by figuring out the input data slices that fall in the same time period as the output slice to be produced.
trans-unit.target: Data factory computes these dependencies automatically by figuring out the input data slices that fall in the same time period as the output slice to be produced.

trans-unit.source: If any of the 24 input slices is not available (due to processing happening in an activity upstream that produces the that slice for example) data factory will wait for the input slice to be ready before kicking off the daily activity run.
trans-unit.target: If any of the 24 input slices is not available (due to processing happening in an activity upstream that produces the that slice for example) data factory will wait for the input slice to be ready before kicking off the daily activity run.

trans-unit.source: Let’s consider another scenario.
trans-unit.target: Let’s consider another scenario.

trans-unit.source: Suppose you have a Hive activity that processes two input datasets, one of them has new data daily but one of them gets new data every week.
trans-unit.target: Suppose you have a Hive activity that processes two input datasets, one of them has new data daily but one of them gets new data every week.

trans-unit.source: Suppose you wanted to do a join across the two inputs and produce an output daily.
trans-unit.target: Suppose you wanted to do a join across the two inputs and produce an output daily.

trans-unit.source: The simple approach so far where data factory automatically figures out the right input slices to process by including input data slices aligned to the output data slice’s time period no longer works.
trans-unit.target: The simple approach so far where data factory automatically figures out the right input slices to process by including input data slices aligned to the output data slice’s time period no longer works.

trans-unit.source: You need a way to specify for every activity run the data factory should use last week’s data slice for the weekly input dataset.
trans-unit.target: You need a way to specify for every activity run the data factory should use last week’s data slice for the weekly input dataset.

trans-unit.source: You can do that with the help of Azure Data Factory functions as shows below.
trans-unit.target: You can do that with the help of Azure Data Factory functions as shows below.

trans-unit.source: Input1: Azure Blob
trans-unit.target: Input1: Azure Blob

trans-unit.source: First input is Azure blob updated daily.
trans-unit.target: First input is Azure blob updated daily.

trans-unit.source: Input2: Azure Blob
trans-unit.target: Input2: Azure Blob

trans-unit.source: Input2 is Azure blob updated weekly.
trans-unit.target: Input2 is Azure blob updated weekly.

trans-unit.source: Output: Azure Blob
trans-unit.target: Output: Azure Blob

trans-unit.source: One output file will be dropped every day in the folder for the day.
trans-unit.target: One output file will be dropped every day in the folder for the day.

trans-unit.source: Availability of output is set Daily (frequency: Day, interval: 1).
trans-unit.target: Availability of output is set Daily (frequency: Day, interval: 1).

trans-unit.source: Activity: Hive activity in a pipeline
trans-unit.target: Activity: Hive activity in a pipeline

trans-unit.source: The hive activity takes the 2 inputs and produces an output slice every day.
trans-unit.target: The hive activity takes the 2 inputs and produces an output slice every day.

trans-unit.source: You can specify every day’s output slice to depend on last week’s input slice for weekly input as follows.
trans-unit.target: You can specify every day’s output slice to depend on last week’s input slice for weekly input as follows.

trans-unit.target: Variable Name

1. Specify dynamic folder paths and file names while working with Azure Blob and File System datasets.
  2. Specify input dependencies with data factory functions in activity inputs collection.
trans-unit.target:

trans-unit.source: same as above.
trans-unit.target: same as above.

trans-unit.source: Currently data factory requires that the schedule specified in the activity exactly match the schedule specified in availability of the output dataset.
trans-unit.target: Currently data factory requires that the schedule specified in the activity exactly match the schedule specified in availability of the output dataset.

trans-unit.source: This means WindowStart, WindowEnd and SliceStart and SliceEnd always map to the same time period and a single output slice.
trans-unit.target: This means WindowStart, WindowEnd and SliceStart and SliceEnd always map to the same time period and a single output slice.

trans-unit.source: You can use functions in data factory along with above mentioned system variables for the following purposes:
trans-unit.target: You can use functions in data factory along with above mentioned system variables for the following purposes:

trans-unit.source: Specifying data selection queries (see connector articles referenced by the <linkText>Data Movement Activities</linkText><title></title> article.
trans-unit.target: Specifying data selection queries (see connector articles referenced by the <linkText>Data Movement Activities</linkText><title></title> article.

trans-unit.source: The syntax to invoke a data factory function is: $$ for data selection queries and other properties in the activity and datasets.
trans-unit.target: The syntax to invoke a data factory function is: $$ for data selection queries and other properties in the activity and datasets.

trans-unit.source: Specifying input dependencies with data factory functions in activity inputs collection (see sample above).
trans-unit.target: Specifying input dependencies with data factory functions in activity inputs collection (see sample above).

trans-unit.source: $$ is not needed for specifying input dependency expressions.
trans-unit.target: $$ is not needed for specifying input dependency expressions.

trans-unit.source: In the following sample, sqlReaderQuery property in a JSON file is assigned to a value returned by the Text.Format function.
trans-unit.target: In the following sample, sqlReaderQuery property in a JSON file is assigned to a value returned by the Text.Format function.

trans-unit.source: This sample also uses a system variable named WindowStart, which represents the start time of the activity run window.
trans-unit.target: This sample also uses a system variable named WindowStart, which represents the start time of the activity run window.

trans-unit.source: The following tables list all the functions in Azure Data Factory:
trans-unit.target: The following tables list all the functions in Azure Data Factory:

trans-unit.source: Category
trans-unit.target: Category

trans-unit.target: Function

trans-unit.target: Parameters

trans-unit.source: Time
trans-unit.target: Time

trans-unit.source: AddHours(X,Y)
trans-unit.target: AddHours(X,Y)

trans-unit.source:
X: DateTime

Y: int
trans-unit.target:
X: DateTime

Y: int

trans-unit.source:
Adds Y hours to the given time X.

Example: 9/5/2013 12:00:00 PM + 2 hours = 9/5/2013 2:00:00 PM
trans-unit.target:
Adds Y hours to the given time X.

Example: 9/5/2013 12:00:00 PM + 2 hours = 9/5/2013 2:00:00 PM

trans-unit.source: Time
trans-unit.target: Time

trans-unit.source: AddMinutes(X,Y)
trans-unit.target: AddMinutes(X,Y)

trans-unit.source:
X: DateTime

Y: int
trans-unit.target:
X: DateTime

Y: int

trans-unit.source:
Adds Y minutes to X.

Example: 9/15/2013 12: 00:00 PM + 15 minutes = 9/15/2013 12: 15:00 PM
trans-unit.target:
Adds Y minutes to X.

Example: 9/15/2013 12: 00:00 PM + 15 minutes = 9/15/2013 12: 15:00 PM

trans-unit.source: Time
trans-unit.target: Time

trans-unit.source: StartOfHour(X)
trans-unit.target: StartOfHour(X)

trans-unit.source: X: Datetime
trans-unit.target: X: Datetime

trans-unit.source:
Gets the starting time for the hour represented by the hour component of X.

Example: StartOfHour of 9/15/2013 05: 10:23 PM is 9/15/2013 05: 00:00 PM
trans-unit.target:
Gets the starting time for the hour represented by the hour component of X.

Example: StartOfHour of 9/15/2013 05: 10:23 PM is 9/15/2013 05: 00:00 PM

trans-unit.target: Date

trans-unit.target: AddDays(X,Y)

X: DateTime

Y: int
trans-unit.target:

trans-unit.target: Date

trans-unit.source: AddMonths(X,Y)
trans-unit.target: AddMonths(X,Y)

trans-unit.source:
X: DateTime

Y: int
trans-unit.target:
X: DateTime

Y: int

trans-unit.source:
Adds Y months to X.

Example: 9/15/2013 12:00:00 PM + 1 month = 10/15/2013 12:00:00 PM
trans-unit.target:
Adds Y months to X.

Example: 9/15/2013 12:00:00 PM + 1 month = 10/15/2013 12:00:00 PM

trans-unit.target: Date

trans-unit.source: AddQuarters(X,Y)
trans-unit.target: AddQuarters(X,Y)

trans-unit.source:
X: DateTime

Y: int
trans-unit.target:
X: DateTime

Y: int

trans-unit.source:
Adds Y * 3 months to X.

Example: 9/15/2013 12:00:00 PM + 1 quarter = 12/15/2013 12:00:00 PM
trans-unit.target:
Adds Y * 3 months to X.

Example: 9/15/2013 12:00:00 PM + 1 quarter = 12/15/2013 12:00:00 PM

trans-unit.target: Date

trans-unit.target: AddWeeks(X,Y)

trans-unit.target: AddYears(X,Y)

X: DateTime

Y: int
trans-unit.target:
X: DateTime

Y: int

trans-unit.source: Day(X)
trans-unit.target: Day(X)

trans-unit.target: X: DateTime

trans-unit.source:
Gets the day component of X.

Example: Day of 9/15/2013 12:00:00 PM is 9.
trans-unit.target:
Gets the day component of X.

Example: Day of 9/15/2013 12:00:00 PM is 9.

trans-unit.source: Date
trans-unit.target: Date

trans-unit.source: DayOfWeek(X)
trans-unit.target: DayOfWeek(X)

trans-unit.source: X: DateTime
trans-unit.target: X: DateTime

trans-unit.source:
Gets the day of week component of X.

Example: DayOfWeek of 9/15/2013 12:00:00 PM is Sunday.
trans-unit.target:
Gets the day of week component of X.

trans-unit.source: Date
trans-unit.target: Date

trans-unit.source: DayOfYear(X)
trans-unit.target: DayOfYear(X)

trans-unit.source: X: DateTime
trans-unit.target: X: DateTime

trans-unit.source:
Gets the day in the year represented by the year component of X.

Examples:
12/1/2015: day 335 of 2015
12/31/2015: day 365 of 2015
12/31/2016: day 366 of 2016 (Leap Year)
trans-unit.target:
Gets the day in the year represented by the year component of X.

Examples:
12/1/2015: day 335 of 2015
12/31/2015: day 365 of 2015
12/31/2016: day 366 of 2016 (Leap Year)

trans-unit.source: Date
trans-unit.target: Date

trans-unit.source: DaysInMonth(X)
trans-unit.target: DaysInMonth(X)

trans-unit.source: X: DateTime
trans-unit.target: X: DateTime

trans-unit.source:
Gets the days in the month represented by the month component of parameter X.

Example: DaysInMonth of 9/15/2013 are 30 since there are 30 days in the September month.
trans-unit.target:
Gets the days in the month represented by the month component of parameter X.

Example: DaysInMonth of 9/15/2013 are 30 since there are 30 days in the September month.

trans-unit.target: Date

trans-unit.source: EndOfDay(X)
trans-unit.target: EndOfDay(X)

trans-unit.source: X: DateTime
trans-unit.target: X: DateTime

trans-unit.source:
Gets the date-time that represents the end of the day (day component) of X.

Example: EndOfDay of 9/15/2013 05:10:23 PM is 9/15/2013 11:59:59 PM.
trans-unit.target:
Gets the date-time that represents the end of the day (day component) of X.

Example: EndOfDay of 9/15/2013 05:10:23 PM is 9/15/2013 11:59:59 PM.

Example: EndOfMonth of 9/15/2013 05:10:23 PM is 9/30/2013 11:59:59 PM (date time that represents the end of September month)

Gets the end of the month represented by month component of parameter X.

Example: EndOfMonth of 9/15/2013 05:10:23 PM is 9/30/2013 11:59:59 PM (date time that represents the end of September month)

trans-unit.source: Ticks(X)
trans-unit.target: Ticks(X)

trans-unit.source: X: DateTime
trans-unit.target: X: DateTime

trans-unit.source: Gets the ticks property of the parameter X. One tick equals 100 nanoseconds.
trans-unit.target: Gets the ticks property of the parameter X. One tick equals 100 nanoseconds.

trans-unit.source: The value of this property represents the number of ticks that have elapsed since 12:00:00 midnight, January 1, 0001.
trans-unit.target: The value of this property represents the number of ticks that have elapsed since 12:00:00 midnight, January 1, 0001.

trans-unit.source: Text
trans-unit.target: Text

trans-unit.source: Format(X)
trans-unit.target: Format(X)

trans-unit.source: X: String variable
trans-unit.target: X: String variable

trans-unit.source: Formats the text.
trans-unit.target: Formats the text.

trans-unit.source: When using a function within another function, you do not need to use $$ prefix for the inner function.
trans-unit.target: When using a function within another function, you do not need to use $$ prefix for the inner function.

trans-unit.source: For example: $$Text.Format('PartitionKey eq \\'mypkeyfilter_value\\' and RowKey ge \\'{0:yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss}\\'', Time.AddHours(SliceStart, -6)).
trans-unit.target: For example: $$Text.Format('PartitionKey eq \\'mypkeyfilter_value\\' and RowKey ge \\'{0:yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss}\\'', Time.AddHours(SliceStart, -6)).

trans-unit.source: In this example, notice that $$ prefix is not used for the Time.AddHours function.
trans-unit.target: In this example, notice that $$ prefix is not used for the Time.AddHours function.

trans-unit.source: In order to generate a dataset slice by an activity run, data factory uses the following dependency model to determine the relationships between the dataset(s) consumed by an activity and the dataset(s) produced by an activity.
trans-unit.target: In order to generate a dataset slice by an activity run, data factory uses the following dependency model to determine the relationships between the dataset(s) consumed by an activity and the dataset(s) produced by an activity.

trans-unit.source: The time range of the input dataset(s) required to generate the output dataset slice called the dependency period.
trans-unit.target: The time range of the input dataset(s) required to generate the output dataset slice called the dependency period.

trans-unit.source: An activity run generates a dataset slice only after the data slices in input dataset(s) within the dependency period are available.
trans-unit.target: An activity run generates a dataset slice only after the data slices in input dataset(s) within the dependency period are available.

trans-unit.source: It means that all the input slices comprising the dependency period must be in Ready status for the output dataset slice to be produced by an activity run.
trans-unit.target: It means that all the input slices comprising the dependency period must be in Ready status for the output dataset slice to be produced by an activity run.

trans-unit.source: To generate the dataset slice [start, end], a function is needed to map the dataset slice to its dependency period.
trans-unit.target: To generate the dataset slice [start, end], a function is needed to map the dataset slice to its dependency period.

trans-unit.source: This function is essentially a formula that converts the start and end of the dataset slice to the start and end of the dependency period.
trans-unit.target: This function is essentially a formula that converts the start and end of the dataset slice to the start and end of the dependency period.

trans-unit.source: More formally,
trans-unit.target: More formally,

trans-unit.source: where f and g are mapping functions that calculate the start and end of the dependency period for each activity input.
trans-unit.target: where f and g are mapping functions that calculate the start and end of the dependency period for each activity input.

trans-unit.source: As seen in samples shown above in most cases the dependency period is same as the period for the data slice to be produced.
trans-unit.target: As seen in samples shown above in most cases the dependency period is same as the period for the data slice to be produced.

trans-unit.source: In these cases data factory automatically computes the input slices that fall in the dependency period.
trans-unit.target: In these cases data factory automatically computes the input slices that fall in the dependency period.

trans-unit.source: For example: In the aggregation sample above where output is produced daily and input data is available every hour, the data slice period is 24 hours.
trans-unit.target: For example: In the aggregation sample above where output is produced daily and input data is available every hour, the data slice period is 24 hours.

trans-unit.source: Data factory finds the relevant hourly input slices for this time period and makes the output slice dependent on the input slice.
trans-unit.target: Data factory finds the relevant hourly input slices for this time period and makes the output slice dependent on the input slice.

trans-unit.source: You can also provide your own mapping for the dependency period as shown in the sample above where one of the inputs was weekly and the output slice is produced daily.
trans-unit.target: You can also provide your own mapping for the dependency period as shown in the sample above where one of the inputs was weekly and the output slice is produced daily.

trans-unit.source: A dataset can optionally have a validation policy defined that specifies how the data generated by a slice execution can be validated before it is ready for consumption.
trans-unit.target: A dataset can optionally have a validation policy defined that specifies how the data generated by a slice execution can be validated before it is ready for consumption.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Creating datasets</linkText><title></title> article for details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Creating datasets</linkText><title></title> article for details.

trans-unit.source: In such cases, once the slice has finished execution, the output slice status is changed to Waiting with a substatus of Validation.
trans-unit.target: In such cases, once the slice has finished execution, the output slice status is changed to Waiting with a substatus of Validation.

trans-unit.source: Once the slices are validated, the slice status changes to Ready.
trans-unit.target: Once the slices are validated, the slice status changes to Ready.

trans-unit.source: If a data slice has been produced but did not pass the validation, activity runs for downstream slices depending on the slice that failed validation will not be processed.
trans-unit.target: If a data slice has been produced but did not pass the validation, activity runs for downstream slices depending on the slice that failed validation will not be processed.

trans-unit.source: The various states of data slices in data factory are covered in the <linkText>Monitor and manage pipelines</linkText><title></title> article.
trans-unit.target: The various states of data slices in data factory are covered in the <linkText>Monitor and manage pipelines</linkText><title></title> article.

trans-unit.source: A dataset can be marked as external (as shown in the JSON below), implying it was not generated with Azure Data Factory.
trans-unit.target: A dataset can be marked as external (as shown in the JSON below), implying it was not generated with Azure Data Factory.

trans-unit.source: In such a case, the Dataset policy can have an additional set of parameters describing validation and retry policy for the dataset.
trans-unit.target: In such a case, the Dataset policy can have an additional set of parameters describing validation and retry policy for the dataset.

trans-unit.source: Please see <linkText>Creating Pipelines</linkText><title></title> for a description of all the properties.
trans-unit.target: Please see <linkText>Creating Pipelines</linkText><title></title> for a description of all the properties.

trans-unit.source: Similar to datasets that are produced by data factory the data slices for external data need to be ready before dependent slices can be processed.
trans-unit.target: Similar to datasets that are produced by data factory the data slices for external data need to be ready before dependent slices can be processed.
